author: mini_mads1980
title: Poorest Fire Outing for the City Comic
review:
Overview

This is the fourth Fire outing for the Lego City Comic.  Bobby McBright appears in this particular issue, and is possibly the second time we have seen him.  This issue was on sale between 19th February 2020 and 17th March 2020.

Packet

The packet shows the drone flying whilst being controlled by Bobby.  In the background there is a fire helicopter that does not appear to be based on any retail set.  On the back the 1:1 image has one of the propeller blades, which is too big for the box and looks quite good as it bursts from the page.

Minifigure

Bobby, in this exact configuration, appears in this set and the GWP 30361: Fire ATV.  Therefore, if you missed out on the GWP then this could have been the best way of getting the Minifigure.  It's bound to appear as a secondary set on the front of the comic in the future, so don't despair if you haven't got him yet.

The torso appears in 21 sets and legs 26, so would be easy to source should you wish.  The red hat is new in the last couple of years but again readily available.  Bobby's head too is very common and has appeared in a few of the City themes since 2017, including Issue 4 of the City Comic as a Fireman!

Main Build/Parts

This is a very poor build and adds nothing to the Minifigure in my view.  The drone you get with Series 20 of the Collectable Minifigures would have been a great addition, but sadly this is made up of 11 pieces that you need to be told is a drone.  But for the colour scheme you would struggle to link it to the City Fire line.

Verdict

It's fair to say that this is by far my least favourite of the City Fire sets attached to the City Comic.  To date we have had four, and the last one (951905) was pretty bad - only saved as it had the first female Minifigure for the Comic line contained in it.

The only reason to get this would be for Bobby McBright, who appears to have switched role at the Fire Department.

I scored the overall as 2 purely to take into consideration the value for money, and that is only because you get the comic and two sets for £4.99.  However, the additional set for me was 951910 which I only scored 2 as well.  Therefore, if you missed this issue you have not really missed anything.  Also, the sets don't compliment each other in play value, but always nice to get more Lego, so I gave it an extra point.

The next issue will feature a new construction set with a nice looking bulldozer and I look forward to it.
